solution_line_template: On Sunday they sold twice as many books in-store as the {books_sold_in_store_saturday} books on Saturday so they sold {multiplier_sunday_in_store}*{books_sold_in_store_saturday} = <<{multiplier_sunday_in_store}*{books_sold_in_store_saturday}={books_sold_in_store_sunday}>>{books_sold_in_store_sunday}

They sold {books_sold_online_saturday} books online on Saturday and increased that number by {increase_online_sunday} books on Sunday for a total of {books_sold_online_saturday}+{increase_online_sunday} = <<{books_sold_online_saturday}+{increase_online_sunday}={books_sold_online_sunday}>>{books_sold_online_sunday}

Over the weekend they sold {books_sold_in_store_saturday}+{books_sold_online_saturday}+{books_sold_in_store_sunday}+{books_sold_online_sunday} = <<{books_sold_in_store_saturday}+{books_sold_online_saturday}+{books_sold_in_store_sunday}+{books_sold_online_sunday}={total_books_sold_weekend}>>{total_books_sold_weekend} books

They started off with {initial_books} books and sold {total_books_sold_weekend} books which brings the inventory to {initial_books}-{total_books_sold_weekend} = <<{initial_books}-{total_books_sold_weekend}={books_after_sales}>>{books_after_sales} books

They have {books_after_sales} books and received a shipment for {shipment_books} bringing their inventory to {books_after_sales}+{shipment_books} = <<{books_after_sales}+{shipment_books}={final_books}>>{final_books} books
